Dear BREANNA NELSON:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on August
19, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include
the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of
the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The time
between the variable interval checks shall not exceed
fifteen minutes.
Bed check logs from 7/16/25-8/14/25 were reviewed. Logs showed checks being
completed every 15 minutes exactly rather than variable intervals not to exceed
15 minutes.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the
services provided while in residence, including
medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident's needs that
remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility
after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental
follow up that is needed, have been reviewed with
the resident and with the parent and with the
responsible case manager.
One out of two closed youth files reviewed did not have a brief summary of the
services provided while at the facility, did not have an assessment of the
resident's needs that remain to be met, did not have information on any services
that will be provided by the facility after discharge, and did not contain a
statement that the discharge plan recommendations were reviewed with the
resident and responsible case manager.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Bed checks need to be completed at variable intervals not to exceed 15-minutes.
They cannot be completed at 15-minute intervals exactly. Consultant virtually

attended a team meeting for the facility on 8/22/25 to train staff about the
requirements.
• Service plans must be completed outside of MiSACWIS if there are delays in
getting the MiSACWIS case open within 30 days of admission. The report
completed outside of the system should then be uploaded to MiSACWIS and put
in the youth’s file to show compliance.
• On 8/19/25, the facility was provided with an example of the DHS-69 Action
Summary with the information required under Rule 400.4166 highlighted to
ensure compliance with discharge plans.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was not requested or required any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had one CAP due to their 2024 Interim report findings. The facility was
found in violation of Rule 113(1)(i) regarding central registry checks for staff. The
facility created a tracking spreadsheet to document compliance and also created
a hiring manager checklist with the clearance requirements listed to ensure
compliance ongoing.
Financial Overview
The facility’s budget and December 2023 financial audit were reviewed and there
were no concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted the facility successfully implemented their 2024
Interim CAP, and has maintained compliance with Rule 113(1)(i) since then. There
were no unplanned discharges since the last inspection. CA noted the program
has a Quality Team who reviews all CAPs, rules, and policies. The team meets

monthly and reports quarterly performance monitoring data to the Child and Family
Quality Specialists.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported it has been great getting the youth involved in activities and
spending time with them. One staff reported wishing there were more outings and
more Samaritas events where they could see youth from the other houses. The
same staff reported youth don’t get out of the house often and don’t ask to leave
the house much, but when offered opportunities to leave the house, they love it.
Staff reported there’s always room for communication to improve regarding what’s
going on with the youth as sometimes information is shared with a few people but
not to the whole group. Staff reported they feel very supported, and they feel
training is thorough and effective. However, one staff reported having more
training surrounding cultures and cross-cultures for staff to avoid assumptions
being made or things getting lost in translation would be helpful. One staff reported
the transition in managing all URM youth instead of having UC youth (as of
December 2024) has been an adjustment, but they’re beginning to settle in. The
same staff reported youth cook more independently now, make their own
appointments, and are gaining more independent living skills, which is great
because they have more confidence and skills when leaving the program.
Youth reported they feel safe at the facility and staff care about them. They
reported they have staff they can talk to if they have a problem or need assistance.
They reported the food is good and they get enough food. No youth reported any
concerns about the facility or staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was completed on 8/15/25 and no safety concerns
were noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
